image.altText: Peter Dutton, standing outdoors in a suit and tie, looks ahead with a neutral expression. Behind him is the wall of a house.

props.synopsis: A Four Corners investigation finds Opposition Leader Peter Dutton failed to disclose his interest in a family trust for two years.

title.children: 'Public has a right to know': Peter Dutton failed to declare interest in a family trust

image.altText: Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese smiling on rainbow background.

props.synopsis: While there is broad agreement that Peter Dutton has a narrower path to victory than Anthony Albanese, campaigners are bracing for the unexpected.

title.children: Here's the state of play in dozens of seats that could decide the election

image.altText: A photo collage shows three voters from the seat of Deakin.

props.synopsis: Voters in Australia's most marginal seat tell us they're worried no-one is equipped to deliver the future they want.

title.children: 'Just trying to win': What 19 key voters have to say about our leaders

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks to reporters at Salamander Bay in NSW

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton has branded offensive remarks made by the Liberal candidate for Fowler as "inappropriate", but says he is "not going to take a lecture from the prime minister" over the issue. Follow live.

title.children: Dutton labels the Greens an ‘antisemitic, Jew-hating’ party

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Dutton calls Greens an 'antisemitic, Jew-hating' party
A quick recap of Albanese's press conference

image.altText: Coloured food trucks alongside a road cluttered with debris and a Vancouver Police truck in the background

props.synopsis: Canadian police have charged 30-year-old Kai-Ji Adam Lo with murder over a car ramming attack at a Filipino heritage festival in the city of Vancouver that killed 11 people.

title.children: 'Darkest day in Vancouver's history': Man charged with murder over car attack

image.altText: Roy Conry stands behind a desk with equipment on it

props.synopsis: Toolmaking and engineering pattern-making was once a thriving industry and is still a critical part of the supply chain in Australia, but the sector has shrunk, leaving the remaining tradies struggling to keep up with demand.

title.children: The dying trade critical to keeping Australian manufacturing alive

image.altText: Australian bank notes laid on white background

props.synopsis: The ASX opens 1 per cent higher after Wall Street rallies on easing trade tensions. Ratings agency S&P warns election promises may pressure Australia's credit rating. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: S&P warns election spending promises may risk Australia's AAA credit rating

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: AAA credit rating under threat as election spending spree continues
ASX up 1% on opening, banks lift again

image.altText: Dutton on April 2

props.synopsis: The election race has solidified into a character contest and a clash between two very different styles of leadership.

title.children: Dutton appeals to undecided voters by trying to show a 'softer side'

image.altText: An illustration of climate change for the Australian Federal Election 2025.

props.synopsis: As the election campaign draws to a close, it's safe to say both major parties have been quiet on climate change. While Labor policies have made some progress to decarbonise, the Coalition threatens to scrap or weaken them.

title.children: Where do the major parties stand on climate? Turns out they’re worlds apart

image.altText: A woman in yellow jumper holding shopping bag faces a supermarket shelf full of colourful wrapped foods.

props.synopsis: Both Labor and the Coalition have announced tax concessions ahead of polling day on May 3. Here's how much you could potentially save under Labor or the Coalition.

title.children: Major parties have pledged tax relief. Calculate what it means for you

image.altText: Headshot of Donna Nelson wearing a black shirt with a garden behind her.

props.synopsis: Grandmother Donna Nelson sits alone in a Japanese jail for 23 hours a day, far from the life she planned with her online boyfriend of two years. The court accepted the 59-year-old was love scammed, but sentenced her anyway.

title.children: Donna's trip of a lifetime landed her in jail in Japan

image.altText: Woman stands in courtroom, woman in road in top left-hand corner

props.synopsis: The opening day of the inquest has been told there was evidence of "rudimentary planning" and in the years prior Joel Cauchi had purchased knives which were used on the day of the attack that killed six people.

title.children: Bondi Junction stabbings inquest to review killer's 'preoccupation with death'

image.altText: drone shot of a hospital sitting among leafy suburban streets

props.synopsis: I've seen the future of an important part of Australia's healthcare system — a private hospital owned by a health insurance company.

title.children: A private hospital opens in Melbourne with no out-of-pocket costs

image.altText: A photo of China's crewed submersible, the Fendhouze, held aloft above the water before going in.

props.synopsis: China's new cable-cutter has been making headlines, but how much of a threat is it really?

title.children: What China's new cable-cutter signals for Australia

image.altText: a campaign poster for Vivek Singha the Liberal candidate for Fowler in Western Sydney

props.synopsis: The ABC uncovers social media posts by Liberal candidate Vivek Singha in which he repeatedly uses a derogatory term for Indigenous Australians and takes aim at Environment Minister Tanya Plibersek over a personal family matter.

title.children: Liberal candidate for Western Sydney seat apologises for offensive posts

image.altText: A boys sits on red blanket with a white bandage over his head

props.synopsis: Seven-year-old Ali Faraj Faraj, covered in blood and dust, could be seen crying amongst the rubble of a home in Gaza City. His father and five sisters were killed in the strike on Thursday.

title.children: A blast threw this 7yo on his neighbour's roof — his father's body lay feet away

image.altText: A photo of Samuel Hockey.

props.synopsis: A new nasal spray that uses a form of ketamine to treat stubborn depression will be added to the PBS, making treatment cheaper for thousands of Australians.

title.children: Ketamine-based nasal spray 'just the beginning' for depression patients

image.altText: Pope Francis hugs Filipino Cardinal Luis Antonio Tagle.

props.synopsis: There's increasing hope among Catholics in the Philippines that one of their own, Cardinal Luis Tagle, might become Asia's first Pope.

title.children: Frontrunner for next pope seen as open minded, but hasn't led change

image.altText: A hand holding a phone with a computer in the background

props.synopsis: As artificial intelligence becomes more prolific in modern society, scammers are using the tool to produce highly convincing scams that leave even the experts second-guessing.

title.children: The ABC fact-checked an AI scam. Here's what we found

image.altText: Emergency service workers standing on the street at night.

props.synopsis: Vancouver Police say 11 people are dead and at least 20 more have been injured after a car ramming attack in the Canadian city. Here's what we know.

title.children: What we know about the deadly 'car ramming attack' in Canada

image.altText: Donald Trump wearing a black overcoat, white shirt, navy pants and white MAGA hat raising his left fist in the air

props.synopsis: A day after meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the Vatican, Donald Trump says the US has "the confines of a deal" and Russia should sign it.

title.children: Trump tells Putin to 'stop shooting' and sign peace deal with Ukraine

image.altText: A doctor using a stethoscope on a patient.

props.synopsis: Rural Queensland residents who are travelling up to 180 kilometres to see a doctor say they are disappointed with the lack of focus on health this federal election.

title.children: Towns with no doctors say election health promises a 'bandaid' approach

image.altText: Arne Slot and Virgil van Dijk look up at the crowd together and smile after the clinching the title

props.synopsis: Replacing an iconic manager at a famous club is often a poisoned chalice, but Arne Slot responded to the impossible task of following up Jürgen Klopp by doing the unthinkable.

title.children: Having been given an impossible task, Arne Slot delivers in spades for Liverpool

image.altText: Military personnel in uniform standing in formation at Anzac Day celebrations.

props.synopsis: A 15-year-old boy will appear in court after a stolen car delayed Anzac Day commemorations in Townsville, Australia's largest garrison city.

title.children: Boy charged after stolen car forces Anzac Day marchers off street

image.altText: Nathan Brown promotes a multi bet on television.

props.synopsis: The Sportsbet "live odds" segments hosted by former player Nathan Brown was an AFL television broadcast mainstay for years. Why have they suddenly stopped?

title.children: After the losses were revealed, these Sportsbet TV segments stopped

image.altText: A medium shot of a black truck hearse

props.synopsis: A West Australian funeral home boss says a coffin getting soaked in the rain sparked the idea for what he says is the world's first enclosed truck hearse.

title.children: Personalised hearses rise in popularity for final farewells

image.altText: Four soldiers wearing black protective clothing and helmets holding an unfurled Chinese flag on a white sandbank

props.synopsis: Chinese state media says Beijing's coast guard has "implemented maritime control" over the Tiexian Reef during an ongoing battle for control with the Philippines.

title.children: China 'deals with' Filipinos on disputed Spratly Islands sandbank

image.altText: An Asian man and a South Asian woman

props.synopsis: 'Cross-cultural kids' Kevin Han and Muna Hamid were both born in Australia to migrant families but they had very different childhoods. Now as adults, they reflect on their identity-shaping experiences and share the struggles and strengths of their upbringings.

title.children: 'Cross-cultural kids' on what it's really like to grow up in Australia

image.altText: Kristi Noem standing emotionless in a black top in front of a blurred backdrop of a US flag

props.synopsis: A man suspected of stealing US Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem's purse while she was at a Washington DC restaurant has been arrested by the nation's Secret Service.

title.children: Suspect arrested for stealing US homeland security secretary's purse

image.altText: A hole filled with brown water infront of a blue house.

props.synopsis: There is an unshakeable spirit in this historic Queensland town — and it's not the first time it's almost been wiped off the map by floods.

title.children: Floods washed away this town and it may not survive

image.altText: A digital illustration of a large housing development in the rural area, beside a lake.

props.synopsis: The company behind a controversial planned housing development in Darwin's rural area has relaunched its bid, years after it was rejected under a different name.

title.children: Proposal for 4,000 new Darwin homes relaunched years after rejection

image.altText: A handful of banana prawns in a white bowl sitting on grass.

props.synopsis: Banana prawn fishers in the Gulf of Carpentaria are facing the toughest start to the season many can remember, but consumers may be protected from the fallout.

title.children: Fishers struggle to find banana prawns in ocean after rain comes too late

image.altText: Two men standing in front of a pen of emus holding slouch hats with Emu plumes

props.synopsis: Emu feathers on a slouch hat are a powerful symbol of the Australian Light Horse, and two army veterans are combining their skills so the tradition lives on.

title.children: Army veteran mates keep emu plume tradition alive for today's soldiers
